Jo Bennett

To me the left believes that power should reside in the hands of the many and not the few, not just political power but economic as well - collective ownership of the means of production, an end to the appropriation of the fruits of labour by the capitalist class. Until this can be achieved the effects of the capitalist system have to be mitigated by the redistribution of wealth and the provision of state services such as healthcare and education. The state has no power to regulate the private lives of individuals, only their impact on others.
 
 Foreign policy is internationalist, class distinctions are more important than national ones. Respect for international law, ultimate pursuit of disarmament.

James

From a European perspective, the political left means a socialist party. Socialism is a wide term with two principal meanings:
 
 1). In Marxist theory, socialism is understood as a system of production relations that is supposed to characterize the transitional stage between capitalism and full communism.
 
 2). The theory and practice of socialism can be construed as a broad and comprehensive outlook on the human condition.
 
 In America, the meaning is more confused. The Democratic party and people who have "liberal" sympathies are often referred to as "the left". But there is no socialist party in the United States that is active at a national level. (There may be tiny groups who call themselves socialist but who have no influence on the national scene). 
 
 It's true that references to "the left" may be unthinking and pejorative, but the same applies to political, social, and cultural conservatives who are often referred to by the catch-all disparagement of "right wing" or "far right wing". 
 
 James.

 Another Symbiote quote: "You're considering "the wealthy" and "the poor" as some kind of homogenous entity with coordinated decision making, that is, they all act in the same way according to their class interests. Preference scales vary between individuals, not between classes of individuals."
 
 To me, this has strong socialist leanings in the rhetoric. He envisions a classless society (at least econmically). 
 The wealth you have, is the wealth you choose to have, so economical decisions are across the board.
 
 Consumer decisions are not based on economical standing. Rich and poor are unified by the invisible hand which causes all to strive for a strong GNP, and easily attain the leve of financial success they choose.
 As I see it, the rhetoric says he wants what the classic anarchist wants. Just an upside way of getting there.

simone

Locke was more of a libertarian, not liberal. And a very religious one at that. Governmental liberalism and libertarianism are incompatible concepts, IMO.
From an article in the sixth edition of Columbia Encyclopedia:
 
 http://www.bartleby.com/65/lo/Locke-Jo.html
 
 
Locke is most renowned for his political theory. Contradicting Thomas Hobbes, Locke believed that the original state of nature was happy and characterized by reason and tolerance. In that state all people were equal and independent, and none had a right to harm another's "life, health, liberty, or possessions." The state was formed by social contract because in the state of nature each was his own judge, and there was no protection against those who lived outside the law of nature. The state should be guided by natural law.
 
 Rights of property are very important, because each person has a right to the product of his or her labor. Locke forecast the labor theory of value. The policy of governmental checks and balances, as delineated in the Constitution of the United States, was set down by Locke, as was the doctrine that revolution in some circumstances is not only a right but an obligation. At Shaftesbury's behest, he contributed to the Fundamental Constitutions for the Carolinas; the colony's proprietors, however, never implemented the document.
 
 Locke based his ethical theories upon belief in the natural goodness of humanity. The inevitable pursuit of happiness and pleasure, when conducted rationally, leads to cooperation, and in the long run private happiness and the general welfare coincide. . . .

Phunting

Anybody else take the moral compass quiz?
Yes indeed. Although I feel it is slightly flawed too. The economic scale is fine, but personally I am fairly libertarian when it comes to things like prostitution, homosexuality, religion, and to some extent drugs yet am very authoritarian over crime, security the military and so on. In the end I feel that it doesn't matter what a person does to themselves, but when they threaten society we have a problem. However most 2D models average these two out and you end up centrist which is inaccurate.
 
 I think the best one is based of the Nolan model with three dimensions: economic, personal and political. It makes a lot more sense, although it doesn't have a fancy clickable test it's described here:
 
 http://www.friesian.com/quiz.htm
